issue.title: Improve support for proxy models
issue.body:
Related issues: #4973, #2480
Supersedes: #5202

Going for complete proxy model support here, instead of just for Page models (although, Page models are where most changes are needed)

Before these changes:

- You could register a non-page proxy model via modeladmin, the proxy model permissions would be assignable via the Group add/edit views, and those same permissions would be used to protect view access
- You could register a proxy model as a Snippet, but only the **concrete/parent** model permissions would be assignable via the Group add/edit views, and would be used to protect view access
- You could define a proxy Page type. But, when creating instances of that page type, the `content_type` value would be set to that of the **concrete/parent** model, meaning only instances of that model could be accessed via `Page.specific`, `Page.specific_deferred`, or `PageQuerySet.specific()`
- Checking of `Page.subpage_types` and `Page.parent_page_types` would only recognise **concrete/parent** types, leading to unexpected failures.

With these changes:

- Support in modeladmin remains unchanged, but is now tested.
- When registering a proxy model as a Snippet, the permissions for the proxy model are correctly registered, are assignable via the Group add/edit views, and are used to protect view access. (NOTE: will need outlining under upgrade considerations in release notes).
- When creating proxy Page type instances, the `content_type` value is correctly set to that of the proxy model, and instances of that model class are correctly returned by `Page.specific`, `Page.specific_deferred`, or `PageQuerySet.specific()`. Where possible, these methods have been upgraded to take advantage of the reduced need for 'table hopping' associated with MTI.
- Checking of `Page.subpage_types` and `Page.parent_page_types` works correctly

comment.body:
A few of questions, if anyone can help:

**Audit logs**: If you're actioning something for a proxy model instance, you're really actioning something for all variations of that object, so I feel the correct behaviour is to store the concrete model `ContentType`. However, the current behaviour is to use the `ContentType` for the proxy model if the instance is one.. Should this be updated?
- https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/blob/main/wagtail/models/audit_log.py#L109-L111

**Revisions**: If a revision is published for a proxy model, those changes are applied to the concrete instance AND any other proxy representations of it too. With that in mind, I feel the correct behaviour is to store the `ContentType` of the concrete model. However, the current behaviour is to use the `ContentType` for the proxy model if the instance is one. Should this be updated?:
- https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/blob/main/wagtail/models/__init__.py#L263
- https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/blob/main/wagtail/models/__init__.py#L2672
- https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/blob/main/wagtail/models/__init__.py#L2609

**Reference index**: Any references to an object from a proxy model instance are really references from the concrete model instance, as it's the same data, and that same data is used by of its proxy representations - they shouldn't count as individual/separate references. Therefore, I feel `content_type` on that model should be storing the concrete model type too, but that is not how it works currently. Should this also be updated?
- https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/blob/main/wagtail/models/reference_index.py#L357

@@ -63,7 +63,7 @@ def get_object_usage(obj):
 
 def popular_tags_for_model(model, count=10):
     """Return a queryset of the most frequently used tags used on this model class"""
-    content_type = ContentType.objects.get_for_model(model)
+    content_type = ContentType.objects.get_for_model(model, for_concrete_model=False)
comment.body: @gasman I'm not 100% sure this is correct. I think it might actually be better the other way around, but I'm not sure the entries are stored that way.

@@ -0,0 +1,49 @@
+# Proxy models
+
+[Proxy models](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/stable/topics/db/models/#proxy-models) are a way to model polymorphism in Django; where multiple variations of a model share the same fields (defined on a concrete 'parent' model) but differ in other ways. For example, they might implement one or more model methods differently, or set different values on the class to affect certain behaviours (e.g. `template_name`, `search_fields`, `content_panels`).
+
+## Support in Wagtail
+
+As of Wagtail version 5.0, proxy models can be:

commits.message: Use versionadded in advanced topic docs
BaseDjangoAuthPermissionPolicy._content_type should return a proxy model content type where the model is a proxy model
Audit log entries should use the concrete content type, so that logs for different representations of the same underlying object are stored (and can be accessed) consistently

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -178,7 +178,15 @@ def get_streamfield_names(model_class):
 
 class BasePageManager(models.Manager):
     def get_queryset(self):
-        return self._queryset_class(self.model).order_by("path")
+        qs = self._queryset_class(self.model).order_by("path")
+        if self.model._meta.proxy:
+            # Because we store a `content_type` for every page, and proxy models have a
+            # unique `content_type`, we can automatically filter querysets requested from
+            # proxy models, so that they only include page saved from that model. Without
+            # this, all pages that share the concrete parent type would be included;
+            # which is generally less useful.
+            return qs.exact_type(self.model)
comment.body: Good spot. Thanks @gasman! Fixed in 0e0ad73

pull_request.title: Defer snippet registration until models are loaded
pull_request.body:
Fixes #9586. All calls to `register_snippet` that happen before `WagtailSnippetsAppConfig.ready` are now queued up and processed once we are sure models are fully loaded. This avoids any issues with unloaded models during viewset construction, as seen when subclassing django-filters's FilterSet.

Unfortunately I can't see any good way of adding a test for this - it seems to me that this bug ought to have surfaced on our test environment already, given that the app defining the custom user model is [right at the end of INSTALLED_APPS](https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/blob/main/wagtail/test/settings.py#L185-L191) and there are surely calls to `register_snippet` in models.py files before that point. In any case, this does resolve the issue when testing against the test case described in https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/issues/9586#issuecomment-1302425868.

+        # add it to the list of registrations to be processed by register_deferred_snippets
+        DEFERRED_REGISTRATIONS.append((model, viewset))
+        return model
+    elif model in SNIPPET_MODELS:
+        # Do not create duplicate registrations of the same model
+        return model
+
+    from wagtail.snippets.views.chooser import SnippetChooserViewSet
+    from wagtail.snippets.views.snippets import SnippetViewSet
+
+    model.get_usage = lambda obj: ReferenceIndex.get_references_to(
+        obj
+    ).group_by_source_object()
+    model.usage_url = get_snippet_usage_url
+    model.get_admin_base_path = get_admin_base_path
+    model.get_admin_url_namespace = get_admin_url_namespace
+
+    if viewset is None:
+        viewset = SnippetViewSet
+    elif isinstance(viewset, str):
+        viewset = import_string(viewset)
+
+    admin_viewset = viewset(
+        model.get_admin_url_namespace(),
+        model=model,
+        url_prefix=model.get_admin_base_path(),
+    )
comment.body: @gasman It might be worth adding a comment above this line (if it is known to be where the problem occurs)

pull_request.title: Defer snippet registration until models are loaded
pull_request.body:
Fixes #9586. All calls to `register_snippet` that happen before `WagtailSnippetsAppConfig.ready` are now queued up and processed once we are sure models are fully loaded. This avoids any issues with unloaded models during viewset construction, as seen when subclassing django-filters's FilterSet.

Unfortunately I can't see any good way of adding a test for this - it seems to me that this bug ought to have surfaced on our test environment already, given that the app defining the custom user model is [right at the end of INSTALLED_APPS](https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/blob/main/wagtail/test/settings.py#L185-L191) and there are surely calls to `register_snippet` in models.py files before that point. In any case, this does resolve the issue when testing against the test case described in https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/issues/9586#issuecomment-1302425868.

pull_request.title: Improve support for proxy models
pull_request.body:
Related issues: #4973, #2480
Supersedes: #5202

Going for complete proxy model support here, instead of just for Page models (although, Page models are where most changes are needed)

Before these changes:

- You could register a non-page proxy model via modeladmin, the proxy model permissions would be assignable via the Group add/edit views, and those same permissions would be used to protect view access
- You could register a proxy model as a Snippet, but only the **concrete/parent** model permissions would be assignable via the Group add/edit views, and would be used to protect view access
- You could define a proxy Page type. But, when creating instances of that page type, the `content_type` value would be set to that of the **concrete/parent** model, meaning only instances of that model could be accessed via `Page.specific`, `Page.specific_deferred`, or `PageQuerySet.specific()`
- Checking of `Page.subpage_types` and `Page.parent_page_types` would only recognise **concrete/parent** types, leading to unexpected failures.

With these changes:

- Support in modeladmin remains unchanged, but is now tested.
- When registering a proxy model as a Snippet, the permissions for the proxy model are correctly registered, are assignable via the Group add/edit views, and are used to protect view access. (NOTE: will need outlining under upgrade considerations in release notes).
- When creating proxy Page type instances, the `content_type` value is correctly set to that of the proxy model, and instances of that model class are correctly returned by `Page.specific`, `Page.specific_deferred`, or `PageQuerySet.specific()`. Where possible, these methods have been upgraded to take advantage of the reduced need for 'table hopping' associated with MTI.
- Checking of `Page.subpage_types` and `Page.parent_page_types` works correctly

labels.description: Ready to merge by anyone in the core team.

issue.title: RuntimeError: Unable to resolve relationship `user` for `wagtailcore.ModelLogEntry`. Django is most likely not initialized, and its apps registry not populated. Ensure Django has finished setup before loading `FilterSet`s

labels.name: status:Unconfirmed
labels.description: Issue, usually a bug, that has not yet been validated as a confirmed problem.

issue.body:
Hi!

I've updated to the LTS 4.1 but this error came out:

```
RuntimeError: Unable to resolve relationship `user` for `wagtailcore.ModelLogEntry`. Django is most likely not initialized, and its apps registry not populated. Ensure Django has finished setup before loading `FilterSet`s.
```

I have the following versions:

Wagtail 4.1
Django 4.0.8
django-filter 22.1]

### My temporal "fix"

I was able to solve this by removing the **_user_** on the **meta** class of **SnippetHistoryReportFilterSet** :

```python
    class Meta:
        model = ModelLogEntry
        fields = ["action", "**_user_**", "timestamp"]
```

This is located at **wagtail/snippets/views/snippets.py**

Is that a logger or something like that? If so, is there a way to disable it in order to use the page?

Thanks!

comment.body:
@gasman I think you're right about `django-filter`. I think my suggestion needs something extra, otherwise users subclassing these viewsets and importing them into `models.py` to pass to `register_snippet()` are only going to bump into the same problem.

In addition to the above, maybe we make the 'viewset' argument accept a python path string? That way, we can keep that 'lazy' until we are ready to register views.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -493,3 +493,18 @@ class EventPage(Page):
 
     objects = EventPageManager()
 ```
+
+### Support for proxy page models
+
+```{versionadded} 5.0```
+
+[Proxy models](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/stable/topics/db/models/#proxy-models) are a way to model polymorphism in Django; where multiple variations of a model share the same fields (defined on a concrete 'parent' model) but differ in other ways. For example, they might implement one or more model methods differently, or set different values on the class to affect certain behaviours (e.g. `template_name`, `search_fields`, `content_panels`).
+
+Because Wagtail stores a reference to the `ContentType` for every page it creates, then uses it to recall pages the page as an instance of that type, proxy models work in exactly the same way as concrete ones. Wagtail simply stores the `ContentType` for the proxy model, and returns an instance of that model when requested.
+
+Unless you are using the `Page` model as the concrete parent, at least one 'join' will be required at the database level to retrieve your pages, so the usual benefit of proxy model use is somewhat diminished. However, proxy page models come with some additional benefits:
+
+1. Using `Page.specific` on an instance of the concrete parent model will assemble the proxy model instance entirely in Python code, without querying the database.
+2. Where proxy model instances are detected in a queryset `PageQuerySet.specific()` will reduce the number of queries it makes to fetch specific pages, instead preferring to 'upgrade' proxy model instances in Python as the queryset is evaluated.
+
+To top it all off, the `PageManager` will automatically detect when a queryset has been requested from a proxy model, and filter it to only include pages of that type. The (often unexpected) default behaviour for proxy model managers is to return **all entries** from the parent model table, regardless of which model was used to save the data originally. If you are thinking of registering proxy models as Snippets or with `wagtail.contrib.modeladmin`, this is something you'll need to be aware of.
comment.body:
To be honest, I'm not really sure that's good advice, as it's really more nuanced than that.

For permission-related code, you should probably always use `for_concrete_model=False`. 

For something like pages, where you want to know the exact ContentType for each object, you probably also want to use `for_concrete_model=False`.

However, there are situations where it's better to store/use the concrete `ContentType` only. For example, when storing translations for instances of proxy models, where the translations are relevant to ALL variations of that instance, rather than just one.

I don't think we can realistically get away from the fact that this is something that needs to be considered on a case-by-case basis. I would suggest we just rely on the test suite to tell us about breakages, and try to keep it in mind during review.

pull_request.title: Improve support for proxy models
pull_request.body:
Related issues: #4973, #2480
Supersedes: #5202

Going for complete proxy model support here, instead of just for Page models (although, Page models are where most changes are needed)

Before these changes:

- You could register a non-page proxy model via modeladmin, the proxy model permissions would be assignable via the Group add/edit views, and those same permissions would be used to protect view access
- You could register a proxy model as a Snippet, but only the **concrete/parent** model permissions would be assignable via the Group add/edit views, and would be used to protect view access
- You could define a proxy Page type. But, when creating instances of that page type, the `content_type` value would be set to that of the **concrete/parent** model, meaning only instances of that model could be accessed via `Page.specific`, `Page.specific_deferred`, or `PageQuerySet.specific()`
- Checking of `Page.subpage_types` and `Page.parent_page_types` would only recognise **concrete/parent** types, leading to unexpected failures.

With these changes:

- Support in modeladmin remains unchanged, but is now tested.
- When registering a proxy model as a Snippet, the permissions for the proxy model are correctly registered, are assignable via the Group add/edit views, and are used to protect view access. (NOTE: will need outlining under upgrade considerations in release notes).
- When creating proxy Page type instances, the `content_type` value is correctly set to that of the proxy model, and instances of that model class are correctly returned by `Page.specific`, `Page.specific_deferred`, or `PageQuerySet.specific()`. Where possible, these methods have been upgraded to take advantage of the reduced need for 'table hopping' associated with MTI.
- Checking of `Page.subpage_types` and `Page.parent_page_types` works correctly

issue.title: DRAFT: Implement AbstractImage.get_renditions()
issue.body:
Where we want to generate multiple renditions for the same image (e.g. from a `{% picture  %}` tag), we should have a method to do that more efficiently. The aim is to do the following things once for the entire set, instead of once for every rendition:
- Query the cache (using `cache.get_many()` instead of `cache.get()`)
- Query the database (if not present in cache) (using `QuerySet.filter()` instead of `QuerySet.get()`
- Read the original image file from source into memory (The largest improvement)
- Save newly created renditions to the database (using `QuerySet.bulk_create()` instead of `QuerySet.create()`)
- Update the cache (using `cache.set_many()` instead of `cache.set()`)

comment.body: One change I'd like to make before adding tests is: Using (the same) `Filter` objects the whole way through, instead of just spec strings, as I think that may make cache key generation a little more efficient (thanks to the `Filter.operations` cached property).

pull_request.title: DRAFT: Implement AbstractImage.get_renditions()
pull_request.body:
Where we want to generate multiple renditions for the same image (e.g. from a `{% picture  %}` tag), we should have a method to do that more efficiently. The aim is to do the following things once for the entire set, instead of once for every rendition:
- Query the cache (using `cache.get_many()` instead of `cache.get()`)
- Query the database (if not present in cache) (using `QuerySet.filter()` instead of `QuerySet.get()`
- Read the original image file from source into memory (The largest improvement)
- Save newly created renditions to the database (using `QuerySet.bulk_create()` instead of `QuerySet.create()`)
- Update the cache (using `cache.set_many()` instead of `cache.set()`)

issue.title: Improve support for proxy models
issue.body:
Related issues: #4973, #2480
Supersedes: #5202

Going for complete proxy model support here, instead of just for Page models (although, Page models are where most changes are needed)

Before these changes:

- You could register a non-page proxy model via modeladmin, the proxy model permissions would be assignable via the Group add/edit views, and those same permissions would be used to protect view access
- You could register a proxy model as a Snippet, but only the **concrete/parent** model permissions would be assignable via the Group add/edit views, and would be used to protect view access
- You could define a proxy Page type. But, when creating instances of that page type, the `content_type` value would be set to that of the **concrete/parent** model, meaning only instances of that model could be accessed via `Page.specific`, `Page.specific_deferred`, or `PageQuerySet.specific()`
- Checking of `Page.subpage_types` and `Page.parent_page_types` would only recognise **concrete/parent** types, leading to unexpected failures.

With these changes:

- Support in modeladmin remains unchanged, but is now tested.
- When registering a proxy model as a Snippet, the permissions for the proxy model are correctly registered, are assignable via the Group add/edit views, and are used to protect view access. (NOTE: will need outlining under upgrade considerations in release notes).
- When creating proxy Page type instances, the `content_type` value is correctly set to that of the proxy model, and instances of that model class are correctly returned by `Page.specific`, `Page.specific_deferred`, or `PageQuerySet.specific()`. Where possible, these methods have been upgraded to take advantage of the reduced need for 'table hopping' associated with MTI.
- Checking of `Page.subpage_types` and `Page.parent_page_types` works correctly

comment.body:
A few of questions, if anyone can help:

**Audit logs**: If you're actioning something for a proxy model instance, you're really actioning something for all variations of that object, so I feel the correct behaviour is to store the concrete model `ContentType`. However, the current behaviour is to use the `ContentType` for the proxy model if the instance is one.. Should this be updated?
- https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/blob/main/wagtail/models/audit_log.py#L109-L111

**Revisions**: If a revision is published for a proxy model, those changes are applied to the concrete instance AND any other proxy representations of it too. With that in mind, I feel the correct behaviour is to store the `ContentType` of the concrete model. However, the current behaviour is to use the `ContentType` for the proxy model if the instance is one. Should this be updated?:
- https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/blob/main/wagtail/models/__init__.py#L263
- https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/blob/main/wagtail/models/__init__.py#L2672
- https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/blob/main/wagtail/models/__init__.py#L2609

**Reference index**: Any references to an object from a proxy model instance are really references from the concrete model instance, as it's the same data, and that same data is used by of its proxy representations - they shouldn't count as individual/separate references. Therefore, I feel `content_type` on that model should be storing the concrete model type too, but that is not how it works currently. Should this also be updated?
- https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/blob/main/wagtail/models/reference_index.py#L357

+# Proxy models
+
+[Proxy models](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/stable/topics/db/models/#proxy-models) are a way to model polymorphism in Django; where multiple variations of a model share the same fields (defined on a concrete 'parent' model) but differ in other ways. For example, they might implement one or more model methods differently, or set different values on the class to affect certain behaviours (e.g. `template_name`, `search_fields`, `content_panels`).
+
+## Support in Wagtail
+
+As of Wagtail version 5.0, proxy models can be:

pull_request.title: Defer snippet registration until models are loaded
pull_request.body:
Fixes #9586. All calls to `register_snippet` that happen before `WagtailSnippetsAppConfig.ready` are now queued up and processed once we are sure models are fully loaded. This avoids any issues with unloaded models during viewset construction, as seen when subclassing django-filters's FilterSet.

Unfortunately I can't see any good way of adding a test for this - it seems to me that this bug ought to have surfaced on our test environment already, given that the app defining the custom user model is [right at the end of INSTALLED_APPS](https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/blob/main/wagtail/test/settings.py#L185-L191) and there are surely calls to `register_snippet` in models.py files before that point. In any case, this does resolve the issue when testing against the test case described in https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/issues/9586#issuecomment-1302425868.

pull_request.title: Defer snippet registration until models are loaded
pull_request.body:
Fixes #9586. All calls to `register_snippet` that happen before `WagtailSnippetsAppConfig.ready` are now queued up and processed once we are sure models are fully loaded. This avoids any issues with unloaded models during viewset construction, as seen when subclassing django-filters's FilterSet.

Unfortunately I can't see any good way of adding a test for this - it seems to me that this bug ought to have surfaced on our test environment already, given that the app defining the custom user model is [right at the end of INSTALLED_APPS](https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/blob/main/wagtail/test/settings.py#L185-L191) and there are surely calls to `register_snippet` in models.py files before that point. In any case, this does resolve the issue when testing against the test case described in https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/issues/9586#issuecomment-1302425868.

pull_request.title: Improve support for proxy models
pull_request.body:
Related issues: #4973, #2480
Supersedes: #5202

Going for complete proxy model support here, instead of just for Page models (although, Page models are where most changes are needed)

Before these changes:

- You could register a non-page proxy model via modeladmin, the proxy model permissions would be assignable via the Group add/edit views, and those same permissions would be used to protect view access
- You could register a proxy model as a Snippet, but only the **concrete/parent** model permissions would be assignable via the Group add/edit views, and would be used to protect view access
- You could define a proxy Page type. But, when creating instances of that page type, the `content_type` value would be set to that of the **concrete/parent** model, meaning only instances of that model could be accessed via `Page.specific`, `Page.specific_deferred`, or `PageQuerySet.specific()`
- Checking of `Page.subpage_types` and `Page.parent_page_types` would only recognise **concrete/parent** types, leading to unexpected failures.

With these changes:

- Support in modeladmin remains unchanged, but is now tested.
- When registering a proxy model as a Snippet, the permissions for the proxy model are correctly registered, are assignable via the Group add/edit views, and are used to protect view access. (NOTE: will need outlining under upgrade considerations in release notes).
- When creating proxy Page type instances, the `content_type` value is correctly set to that of the proxy model, and instances of that model class are correctly returned by `Page.specific`, `Page.specific_deferred`, or `PageQuerySet.specific()`. Where possible, these methods have been upgraded to take advantage of the reduced need for 'table hopping' associated with MTI.
- Checking of `Page.subpage_types` and `Page.parent_page_types` works correctly

labels.name: status:Ready to merge
labels.description: Ready to merge by anyone in the core team.

issue.title: RuntimeError: Unable to resolve relationship `user` for `wagtailcore.ModelLogEntry`. Django is most likely not initialized, and its apps registry not populated. Ensure Django has finished setup before loading `FilterSet`s

labels.name: status:Unconfirmed
labels.description: Issue, usually a bug, that has not yet been validated as a confirmed problem.

issue.body:
Hi!

I've updated to the LTS 4.1 but this error came out:

```
RuntimeError: Unable to resolve relationship `user` for `wagtailcore.ModelLogEntry`. Django is most likely not initialized, and its apps registry not populated. Ensure Django has finished setup before loading `FilterSet`s.
```

I have the following versions:

Wagtail 4.1
Django 4.0.8
django-filter 22.1]

### My temporal "fix"

I was able to solve this by removing the **_user_** on the **meta** class of **SnippetHistoryReportFilterSet** :

```python
    class Meta:
        model = ModelLogEntry
        fields = ["action", "**_user_**", "timestamp"]
```

This is located at **wagtail/snippets/views/snippets.py**

Is that a logger or something like that? If so, is there a way to disable it in order to use the page?

Thanks!

comment.body:
@gasman I think you're right about `django-filter`. I think my suggestion needs something extra, otherwise users subclassing these viewsets and importing them into `models.py` to pass to `register_snippet()` are only going to bump into the same problem.

In addition to the above, maybe we make the 'viewset' argument accept a python path string? That way, we can keep that 'lazy' until we are ready to register views.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -493,3 +493,18 @@ class EventPage(Page):
 
     objects = EventPageManager()
 ```
+
+### Support for proxy page models
+
+```{versionadded} 5.0```
+
+[Proxy models](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/stable/topics/db/models/#proxy-models) are a way to model polymorphism in Django; where multiple variations of a model share the same fields (defined on a concrete 'parent' model) but differ in other ways. For example, they might implement one or more model methods differently, or set different values on the class to affect certain behaviours (e.g. `template_name`, `search_fields`, `content_panels`).
+
+Because Wagtail stores a reference to the `ContentType` for every page it creates, then uses it to recall pages the page as an instance of that type, proxy models work in exactly the same way as concrete ones. Wagtail simply stores the `ContentType` for the proxy model, and returns an instance of that model when requested.
+
+Unless you are using the `Page` model as the concrete parent, at least one 'join' will be required at the database level to retrieve your pages, so the usual benefit of proxy model use is somewhat diminished. However, proxy page models come with some additional benefits:
+
+1. Using `Page.specific` on an instance of the concrete parent model will assemble the proxy model instance entirely in Python code, without querying the database.
+2. Where proxy model instances are detected in a queryset `PageQuerySet.specific()` will reduce the number of queries it makes to fetch specific pages, instead preferring to 'upgrade' proxy model instances in Python as the queryset is evaluated.
+
+To top it all off, the `PageManager` will automatically detect when a queryset has been requested from a proxy model, and filter it to only include pages of that type. The (often unexpected) default behaviour for proxy model managers is to return **all entries** from the parent model table, regardless of which model was used to save the data originally. If you are thinking of registering proxy models as Snippets or with `wagtail.contrib.modeladmin`, this is something you'll need to be aware of.
comment.body:
To be honest, I'm not really sure that's good advice, as it's really more nuanced than that.

For permission-related code, you should probably always use `for_concrete_model=False`. 

For something like pages, where you want to know the exact ContentType for each object, you probably also want to use `for_concrete_model=False`.

However, there are situations where it's better to store/use the concrete `ContentType` only. For example, when storing translations for instances of proxy models, where the translations are relevant to ALL variations of that instance, rather than just one.

I don't think we can realistically get away from the fact that this is something that needs to be considered on a case-by-case basis. I would suggest we just rely on the test suite to tell us about breakages, and try to keep it in mind during review.

pull_request.title: Improve support for proxy models
pull_request.body:
Related issues: #4973, #2480
Supersedes: #5202

Going for complete proxy model support here, instead of just for Page models (although, Page models are where most changes are needed)

Before these changes:

- You could register a non-page proxy model via modeladmin, the proxy model permissions would be assignable via the Group add/edit views, and those same permissions would be used to protect view access
- You could register a proxy model as a Snippet, but only the **concrete/parent** model permissions would be assignable via the Group add/edit views, and would be used to protect view access
- You could define a proxy Page type. But, when creating instances of that page type, the `content_type` value would be set to that of the **concrete/parent** model, meaning only instances of that model could be accessed via `Page.specific`, `Page.specific_deferred`, or `PageQuerySet.specific()`
- Checking of `Page.subpage_types` and `Page.parent_page_types` would only recognise **concrete/parent** types, leading to unexpected failures.

With these changes:

- Support in modeladmin remains unchanged, but is now tested.
- When registering a proxy model as a Snippet, the permissions for the proxy model are correctly registered, are assignable via the Group add/edit views, and are used to protect view access. (NOTE: will need outlining under upgrade considerations in release notes).
- When creating proxy Page type instances, the `content_type` value is correctly set to that of the proxy model, and instances of that model class are correctly returned by `Page.specific`, `Page.specific_deferred`, or `PageQuerySet.specific()`. Where possible, these methods have been upgraded to take advantage of the reduced need for 'table hopping' associated with MTI.
- Checking of `Page.subpage_types` and `Page.parent_page_types` works correctly

issue.title: DRAFT: Implement AbstractImage.get_renditions()
issue.body:
Where we want to generate multiple renditions for the same image (e.g. from a `{% picture  %}` tag), we should have a method to do that more efficiently. The aim is to do the following things once for the entire set, instead of once for every rendition:
- Query the cache (using `cache.get_many()` instead of `cache.get()`)
- Query the database (if not present in cache) (using `QuerySet.filter()` instead of `QuerySet.get()`
- Read the original image file from source into memory (The largest improvement)
- Save newly created renditions to the database (using `QuerySet.bulk_create()` instead of `QuerySet.create()`)
- Update the cache (using `cache.set_many()` instead of `cache.set()`)

comment.body: One change I'd like to make before adding tests is: Using (the same) `Filter` objects the whole way through, instead of just spec strings, as I think that may make cache key generation a little more efficient (thanks to the `Filter.operations` cached property).

issue.title: Improve support for proxy models
issue.body:
Related issues: #4973, #2480
Supersedes: #5202

Going for complete proxy model support here, instead of just for Page models (although, Page models are where most changes are needed)

Before these changes:

- You could register a non-page proxy model via modeladmin, the proxy model permissions would be assignable via the Group add/edit views, and those same permissions would be used to protect view access
- You could register a proxy model as a Snippet, but only the **concrete/parent** model permissions would be assignable via the Group add/edit views, and would be used to protect view access
- You could define a proxy Page type. But, when creating instances of that page type, the `content_type` value would be set to that of the **concrete/parent** model, meaning only instances of that model could be accessed via `Page.specific`, `Page.specific_deferred`, or `PageQuerySet.specific()`
- Checking of `Page.subpage_types` and `Page.parent_page_types` would only recognise **concrete/parent** types, leading to unexpected failures.

With these changes:

- Support in modeladmin remains unchanged, but is now tested.
- When registering a proxy model as a Snippet, the permissions for the proxy model are correctly registered, are assignable via the Group add/edit views, and are used to protect view access. (NOTE: will need outlining under upgrade considerations in release notes).
- When creating proxy Page type instances, the `content_type` value is correctly set to that of the proxy model, and instances of that model class are correctly returned by `Page.specific`, `Page.specific_deferred`, or `PageQuerySet.specific()`. Where possible, these methods have been upgraded to take advantage of the reduced need for 'table hopping' associated with MTI.
- Checking of `Page.subpage_types` and `Page.parent_page_types` works correctly

comment.body:
A few of questions, if anyone can help:

**Audit logs**: If you're actioning something for a proxy model instance, you're really actioning something for all variations of that object, so I feel the correct behaviour is to store the concrete model `ContentType`. However, the current behaviour is to use the `ContentType` for the proxy model if the instance is one.. Should this be updated?
- https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/blob/main/wagtail/models/audit_log.py#L109-L111

**Revisions**: If a revision is published for a proxy model, those changes are applied to the concrete instance AND any other proxy representations of it too. With that in mind, I feel the correct behaviour is to store the `ContentType` of the concrete model. However, the current behaviour is to use the `ContentType` for the proxy model if the instance is one. Should this be updated?:
- https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/blob/main/wagtail/models/__init__.py#L263
- https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/blob/main/wagtail/models/__init__.py#L2672
- https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/blob/main/wagtail/models/__init__.py#L2609

**Reference index**: Any references to an object from a proxy model instance are really references from the concrete model instance, as it's the same data, and that same data is used by of its proxy representations - they shouldn't count as individual/separate references. Therefore, I feel `content_type` on that model should be storing the concrete model type too, but that is not how it works currently. Should this also be updated?
- https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/blob/main/wagtail/models/reference_index.py#L357

 def popular_tags_for_model(model, count=10):

-    content_type = ContentType.objects.get_for_model(model)
+    content_type = ContentType.objects.get_for_model(model, for_concrete_model=False)

+# Proxy models
+
+[Proxy models](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/stable/topics/db/models/#proxy-models) are a way to model polymorphism in Django; where multiple variations of a model share the same fields (defined on a concrete 'parent' model) but differ in other ways. For example, they might implement one or more model methods differently, or set different values on the class to affect certain behaviours (e.g. `template_name`, `search_fields`, `content_panels`).
+
+## Support in Wagtail
+
+As of Wagtail version 5.0, proxy models can be:

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -178,7 +178,15 @@ def get_streamfield_names(model_class):
 
 class BasePageManager(models.Manager):
     def get_queryset(self):
-        return self._queryset_class(self.model).order_by("path")
+        qs = self._queryset_class(self.model).order_by("path")
+        if self.model._meta.proxy:
+            # Because we store a `content_type` for every page, and proxy models have a
+            # unique `content_type`, we can automatically filter querysets requested from
+            # proxy models, so that they only include page saved from that model. Without
+            # this, all pages that share the concrete parent type would be included;
+            # which is generally less useful.
+            return qs.exact_type(self.model)

pull_request.title: Improve support for proxy models
pull_request.body:
Related issues: #4973, #2480
Supersedes: #5202

Going for complete proxy model support here, instead of just for Page models (although, Page models are where most changes are needed)

Before these changes:

- You could register a non-page proxy model via modeladmin, the proxy model permissions would be assignable via the Group add/edit views, and those same permissions would be used to protect view access
- You could register a proxy model as a Snippet, but only the **concrete/parent** model permissions would be assignable via the Group add/edit views, and would be used to protect view access
- You could define a proxy Page type. But, when creating instances of that page type, the `content_type` value would be set to that of the **concrete/parent** model, meaning only instances of that model could be accessed via `Page.specific`, `Page.specific_deferred`, or `PageQuerySet.specific()`
- Checking of `Page.subpage_types` and `Page.parent_page_types` would only recognise **concrete/parent** types, leading to unexpected failures.

With these changes:

- Support in modeladmin remains unchanged, but is now tested.
- When registering a proxy model as a Snippet, the permissions for the proxy model are correctly registered, are assignable via the Group add/edit views, and are used to protect view access. (NOTE: will need outlining under upgrade considerations in release notes).
- When creating proxy Page type instances, the `content_type` value is correctly set to that of the proxy model, and instances of that model class are correctly returned by `Page.specific`, `Page.specific_deferred`, or `PageQuerySet.specific()`. Where possible, these methods have been upgraded to take advantage of the reduced need for 'table hopping' associated with MTI.
- Checking of `Page.subpage_types` and `Page.parent_page_types` works correctly

labels.description: Ready to merge by anyone in the core team.

issue.title: RuntimeError: Unable to resolve relationship `user` for `wagtailcore.ModelLogEntry`. Django is most likely not initialized, and its apps registry not populated. Ensure Django has finished setup before loading `FilterSet`s

labels.name: status:Unconfirmed
labels.description: Issue, usually a bug, that has not yet been validated as a confirmed problem.

issue.body:
Hi!

I've updated to the LTS 4.1 but this error came out:

```
RuntimeError: Unable to resolve relationship `user` for `wagtailcore.ModelLogEntry`. Django is most likely not initialized, and its apps registry not populated. Ensure Django has finished setup before loading `FilterSet`s.
```

I have the following versions:

Wagtail 4.1
Django 4.0.8
django-filter 22.1]

### My temporal "fix"

I was able to solve this by removing the **_user_** on the **meta** class of **SnippetHistoryReportFilterSet** :

```python
    class Meta:
        model = ModelLogEntry
        fields = ["action", "**_user_**", "timestamp"]
```

This is located at **wagtail/snippets/views/snippets.py**

Is that a logger or something like that? If so, is there a way to disable it in order to use the page?

Thanks!

comment.body:
@gasman I think you're right about `django-filter`. I think my suggestion needs something extra, otherwise users subclassing these viewsets and importing them into `models.py` to pass to `register_snippet()` are only going to bump into the same problem.

In addition to the above, maybe we make the 'viewset' argument accept a python path string? That way, we can keep that 'lazy' until we are ready to register views.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -493,3 +493,18 @@ class EventPage(Page):
 
     objects = EventPageManager()
 ```
+
+### Support for proxy page models
+
+```{versionadded} 5.0```
+
+[Proxy models](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/stable/topics/db/models/#proxy-models) are a way to model polymorphism in Django; where multiple variations of a model share the same fields (defined on a concrete 'parent' model) but differ in other ways. For example, they might implement one or more model methods differently, or set different values on the class to affect certain behaviours (e.g. `template_name`, `search_fields`, `content_panels`).
+
+Because Wagtail stores a reference to the `ContentType` for every page it creates, then uses it to recall pages the page as an instance of that type, proxy models work in exactly the same way as concrete ones. Wagtail simply stores the `ContentType` for the proxy model, and returns an instance of that model when requested.
+
+Unless you are using the `Page` model as the concrete parent, at least one 'join' will be required at the database level to retrieve your pages, so the usual benefit of proxy model use is somewhat diminished. However, proxy page models come with some additional benefits:
+
+1. Using `Page.specific` on an instance of the concrete parent model will assemble the proxy model instance entirely in Python code, without querying the database.
+2. Where proxy model instances are detected in a queryset `PageQuerySet.specific()` will reduce the number of queries it makes to fetch specific pages, instead preferring to 'upgrade' proxy model instances in Python as the queryset is evaluated.
+
+To top it all off, the `PageManager` will automatically detect when a queryset has been requested from a proxy model, and filter it to only include pages of that type. The (often unexpected) default behaviour for proxy model managers is to return **all entries** from the parent model table, regardless of which model was used to save the data originally. If you are thinking of registering proxy models as Snippets or with `wagtail.contrib.modeladmin`, this is something you'll need to be aware of.
comment.body:
To be honest, I'm not really sure that's good advice, as it's really more nuanced than that.

For permission-related code, you should probably always use `for_concrete_model=False`. 

For something like pages, where you want to know the exact ContentType for each object, you probably also want to use `for_concrete_model=False`.

However, there are situations where it's better to store/use the concrete `ContentType` only. For example, when storing translations for instances of proxy models, where the translations are relevant to ALL variations of that instance, rather than just one.

I don't think we can realistically get away from the fact that this is something that needs to be considered on a case-by-case basis. I would suggest we just rely on the test suite to tell us about breakages, and try to keep it in mind during review.

- Checking of `Page.subpage_types` and `Page.parent_page_types` would only recognise **concrete/parent** types, leading to unexpected failures.

With these changes:

- Support in modeladmin remains unchanged, but is now tested.
- When registering a proxy model as a Snippet, the permissions for the proxy model are correctly registered, are assignable via the Group add/edit views, and are used to protect view access. (NOTE: will need outlining under upgrade considerations in release notes).
- When creating proxy Page type instances, the `content_type` value is correctly set to that of the proxy model, and instances of that model class are correctly returned by `Page.specific`, `Page.specific_deferred`, or `PageQuerySet.specific()`. Where possible, these methods have been upgraded to take advantage of the reduced need for 'table hopping' associated with MTI.
- Checking of `Page.subpage_types` and `Page.parent_page_types` works correctly

pull_request.title: Improve support for proxy models
pull_request.body:
Related issues: #4973, #2480
Supersedes: #5202

Going for complete proxy model support here, instead of just for Page models (although, Page models are where most changes are needed)

Before these changes:

- You could register a non-page proxy model via modeladmin, the proxy model permissions would be assignable via the Group add/edit views, and those same permissions would be used to protect view access
- You could register a proxy model as a Snippet, but only the **concrete/parent** model permissions would be assignable via the Group add/edit views, and would be used to protect view access
- You could define a proxy Page type. But, when creating instances of that page type, the `content_type` value would be set to that of the **concrete/parent** model, meaning only instances of that model could be accessed via `Page.specific`, `Page.specific_deferred`, or `PageQuerySet.specific()`
- Checking of `Page.subpage_types` and `Page.parent_page_types` would only recognise **concrete/parent** types, leading to unexpected failures.

With these changes:

- Support in modeladmin remains unchanged, but is now tested.
- When registering a proxy model as a Snippet, the permissions for the proxy model are correctly registered, are assignable via the Group add/edit views, and are used to protect view access. (NOTE: will need outlining under upgrade considerations in release notes).
- When creating proxy Page type instances, the `content_type` value is correctly set to that of the proxy model, and instances of that model class are correctly returned by `Page.specific`, `Page.specific_deferred`, or `PageQuerySet.specific()`. Where possible, these methods have been upgraded to take advantage of the reduced need for 'table hopping' associated with MTI.
- Checking of `Page.subpage_types` and `Page.parent_page_types` works correctly

issue.title: RuntimeError: Unable to resolve relationship `user` for `wagtailcore.ModelLogEntry`. Django is most likely not initialized, and its apps registry not populated. Ensure Django has finished setup before loading `FilterSet`s

labels.name: status:Unconfirmed
labels.description: Issue, usually a bug, that has not yet been validated as a confirmed problem.

issue.body:
Hi!

I've updated to the LTS 4.1 but this error came out:

```
RuntimeError: Unable to resolve relationship `user` for `wagtailcore.ModelLogEntry`. Django is most likely not initialized, and its apps registry not populated. Ensure Django has finished setup before loading `FilterSet`s.
```

I have the following versions:

Wagtail 4.1
Django 4.0.8
django-filter 22.1]

### My temporal "fix"

I was able to solve this by removing the **_user_** on the **meta** class of **SnippetHistoryReportFilterSet** :

```python
    class Meta:
        model = ModelLogEntry
        fields = ["action", "**_user_**", "timestamp"]
```

This is located at **wagtail/snippets/views/snippets.py**

Is that a logger or something like that? If so, is there a way to disable it in order to use the page?

Thanks!

comment.body: Suggestion: Would it be viable to update  `register_snippet()`  to simply store the `Snippet: Custom ViewSet`  mappings in another global, then do the actual 'viewset registering' later on?

issue.title: DRAFT: Implement AbstractImage.get_renditions()
issue.body:
Where we want to generate multiple renditions for the same image (e.g. from a `{% picture  %}` tag), we should have a method to do that more efficiently. The aim is to do the following things once for the entire set, instead of once for every rendition:
- Query the cache (using `cache.get_many()` instead of `cache.get()`)
- Query the database (if not present in cache) (using `QuerySet.filter()` instead of `QuerySet.get()`
- Read the original image file from source into memory (The largest improvement)
- Save newly created renditions to the database (using `QuerySet.bulk_create()` instead of `QuerySet.create()`)
- Update the cache (using `cache.set_many()` instead of `cache.set()`)

comment.body: One change I'd like to make before adding tests is: Using (the same) `Filter` objects the whole way through, instead of just spec strings, as I think that may make cache key generation a little more efficient (thanks to the `Filter.operations` cached property).

-            if "renditions" in getattr(self, "_prefetched_objects_cache", {}):

-                    rendition
-                )
-            elif hasattr(self, "prefetched_renditions"):
-                self.prefetched_renditions.append(rendition)
-

-            cache.set(key, rendition)
         except InvalidCacheBackendError:
             pass
+        else:

+            rendition.image = self
+            cache.set(rendition.cache_key, rendition)
